message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medical research for help. The researcher wants to investigate the effect of smoking electronic cigarettes on the risk of developing lung cancer, and thus the most appropriate experimental group is subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes. The control group should consist of subjects who do not smoke, as they will provide a baseline for comparison to determine the effect of smoking electronic cigarettes on the risk of developing lung cancer. Option B compares two smoking groups but does not provide a non-smoking group for comparison. Option C compares subjects with existing lung cancer to those without, which may not accurately measure the risk of developing lung cancer from smoking electronic cigarettes. Option D compares subjects with lung cancer who smoke to those without lung cancer but does not compare the effect of smoking electronic cigarettes specifically.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The researcher wants to study how smoking electronic cigarettes affects the risk of developing lung cancer, so the experimental group should consist of subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes, while the control group should consist of subjects who do not smoke. Option B compares two types of smoking, which is not the focus of the study. Option C compares subjects with and without a specific condition, which does not address the effect of electronic cigarettes on the development of lung cancer. Option D compares smokers with and without lung cancer, which does not control for the effect of smoking in general on the development of lung cancer.

We refer to medical research articles for help. In a cohort study, the researcher would follow a group of individuals over a certain period of time and compare the incidence of the outcome of interest (in this case, lung cancer) between those who smoke electronic cigarettes and those who do not smoke. Therefore, the most appropriate set of experimental and control groups for this study would be subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes and subjects who do not smoke. Option B is not appropriate as it compares two types of smoking, while the researcher is interested in the effect of electronic cigarette use specifically. Option C is not appropriate because both groups already have the outcome of interest (lung cancer). Option D is not appropriate as it compares individuals with different outcomes (lung cancer vs. no lung cancer) rather than comparing exposure to electronic cigarette use.

We refer to the definition of cohort studies on medical websites. A cohort study follows a group of people over time, typically divided into an experimental group and a control group. In this case, the researcher wants to study the effects of smoking electronic cigarettes on the risk of developing lung cancer. Therefore, the experimental group should consist of subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes, while the control group should consist of subjects who do not smoke any type of cigarettes, including electronic cigarettes. Option (A) correctly identifies these groups. Option (B) compares different types of cigarettes, which is not the focus of the study. Option (C) compares subjects with an outcome of interest (lung cancer) and subjects without, which is a retrospective case-control study design, not a cohort study. Option (D) compares subjects with an outcome of interest (lung cancer) based on a specific exposure (smoking), which is also a retrospective case-control study design.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on cohort studies for help. In a cohort study, subjects are followed over time to see if exposures are associated with outcomes. The most appropriate set of experimental and control groups would be subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes (experimental) and subjects who do not smoke (control). Option B is not ideal because it compares different types of smoking, and option C and D do not focus on the exposure of interest (smoking electronic cigarettes).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine and research methodology for help. In a cohort study, the researcher would follow a group of people over time and compare the incidence of lung cancer in those who smoke electronic cigarettes and those who do not smoke. The experimental group would be the subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes, and the control group would be the subjects who do not smoke. Option B and D do not provide a proper control group as they both involve smoking. Option C is not appropriate as it is not comparing the effects of smoking electronic cigarettes specifically.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medical research for help. The most appropriate set of experimental and control groups for a cohort study would be subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes (experimental) and subjects who do not smoke (control). This will allow the researcher to compare the incidence of lung cancer between the two groups and determine if there is a significant difference in risk. Option B involves comparing two groups of smokers, which may not accurately reflect the effects of electronic cigarettes alone. Option C involves selecting subjects based on outcome (lung cancer) rather than exposure (smoking electronic cigarettes). Option D involves selecting subjects based on both outcome and exposure, which may not allow for clear interpretation of the results.

We refer to medical research articles for help. In a cohort study, the researcher follows two groups of people over time, one with a certain exposure (in this case, smoking electronic cigarettes) and the other without. The most appropriate set of experimental and control groups would be the subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes and the subjects who do not smoke, respectively. Option B would not provide a control group that is not exposed to tobacco smoke at all. Option C would limit the study to only individuals with lung cancer, while option D does not have a control group that is not diagnosed with lung cancer at all.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medical research for help. The study aims to investigate the risk of developing lung cancer from smoking electronic cigarettes, so the most appropriate set of experimental and control groups are subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes and subjects who do not smoke. Option B compares two different types of smoking, while options C and D compare lung cancer patients with non-lung cancer patients, which are not relevant to the research question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medical research for help. The researcher wants to study how smoking electronic cigarettes affects the risk of developing lung cancer, so the experimental group should be subjects who smoke electronic cigarettes, while the control group should be subjects who do not smoke any type of cigarettes. Option (B) compares two types of smoking, while option (C) compares subjects with and without lung cancer, which is not relevant to the purpose of the study. Option (D) only includes subjects who smoke, which does not allow for comparison with non-smokers.
